titleStmt.title: AN EXCELLENT conceited Tragedie OF Romeo and Iuliet. As it hath been often (with great applause) plaid publiquely by the right Ho-nourable the L. of Hunsdon his Seruants.

respStmt.name: Kyonnah Price
respStmt.resp: contractions and spelling regularised and homograph function words tagged by
respStmt.name: Hugh Craig

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Character descriptions: Shakespeare, Williams, Quarto: An Excellent conceited Tragedie of Romeo and Iuliet, (Cambridge: Trinity College, 1597).
Romeo; son to Montague Montague; head of two houses at variance with each other Lady Montague; wife to Montague Benvolio; nephew to Montague, and friend to Romeo Mercutio; kinsman to the Prince; and friend to Romeo Juliet; daughter to Capulet Capulet; head of two houses at variance with each other Lady Capulet; wife to Capulet Tybalt; nephew to Lady Capulet Nurse to Juliet Paris; a young nobleman; kinsman to the Prince Frier Laurence; Franciscan Escalus; Prince of Verona Prologue Citizens of Verona
Balthasar; servant to Romeo Abraham; servant to Montague Sampson; servant to Capulet Gregory; servant to Capulet Peter; servant to Juliet's Nurse Page to Paris/Boy An Apothecary Clowne Chief Serving-man Chief Watchman Frier John; Franciscan Musician 1 Musician 2 Musician 3 Captain

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following

sp.l: TWo household Friends alike in dignity,
(In fair Verona, where we lay our Scene)
From civil broils broke into enmity,
Whose civil war makes civil hands unclean.
From forth the fatal loins of these two foes,
A pair of star-crossed Lovers took their life:
Whose misadventures, piteous overthrows,
(Through the continuing of their Fathers' strife,
And death-marked passage of their Parents' rage)
Is now the two hours' traffic of our Stage.
The which if you with patient ears attend,
What here we want we will study to amend.

div1.head:
The most excellent Tragedy of
Romeo and Iuliet.

sp.p: GRegorie, of my word I will carry no coals.
No, for if you do, you should be a Collier.
If I be in choler, I will draw.

Ever while you live, draw your neck out of the
the collar.
I strike quickly being moved.
Aye, but you are not quickly moved to strike.
A Dog of the house of the Mountagues moves me.

To move is to stir, and to be valiant is to stand
to it: therefore (of my word) if thou be moved thou wilt
run away.

There is not a man of them I meet, but I will take
the wall of.

That shows thee a weakling, for the weakest goes
to the wall.

That is true, therefore I will thrust the men from the
wall, and thrust the maids to the walls: nay, thou shalt
see I am a tall piece of flesh.

It is well thou art not fish, for if thou wert thou
wouldst be but poor Iohn.

I will play the tyrant, I will first begin with the maids, and
off with their heads.
The heads of the maids?

Aye the heads of their Maids, or the Maidenheads,
take it in what sense thou wilt.

Nay let them take it in sense that feel it, but here
comes two of the Mountagues.

stage.l: Enter two Seruingmen of the Mountagues.

sp.p: Nay fear not me I warrant thee.
I fear them no more than thee, but draw.

Nay let us have the law on our side, let them begin
first. I will tell thee what I will do, as I go by I will bite my
thumb, which is disgrace enough if they suffer it.

Content, go thou by and bite thy thumb, and I will
come after and frown.

sp.speaker: 1 Mou.
sp.p: Do you bite your thumb at us?
I bite my thumb.

sp.speaker: 2 Mou.
sp.p: Aye but is it at us?
I bite my thumb, is the law on our side?
No.
I bite my thumb.

sp.speaker: 1 Mou.
sp.p: Aye but is it at us?
Say I, here comes my Master's kinsman.

stage.l: They draw, to them enters Tybalt, they fight, to them the
Prince, old Mountague, and his wife, old Capulet and
his wife, and other Citizens and part them.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Rebellious subjects enemies to peace,
On pain of torture, from those bloody hands
Throw your mistempered weapons to the ground.
Three civil brawls bred of an airy word,
By the old Capulet and Mountague,
Have thrice disturbed the quiet of our streets.
If ever you disturb our streets again,
Your lives shall pay the ransom of your fault:
For this time every man depart in peace.
Come Capulet come you along with me,
and Mouutague, come you this afternoon,
To know our farther pleasure in this case,
To old Free-town our common judgement place,
Once more on pain of death each man depart.

sp.speaker: L Mou.
sp.l: Who set this ancient quarrel first abroach?
Speak Nephew, were you by when it began?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Here were the servants of your adversaries,
And yours close fighting ere I did approach.

sp.speaker: L Mou.
sp.l: Ah where is Romeo, saw you him today?
Right glad I am he was not at this fray.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Madam, an hour before the worshipped sun
Peeped through the golden window of the East,
A troubled thought drew me from company:
Where underneath the grove Sycamore,
That Westward rooteth from the City's side,
So early walking might I see your son.
I drew towards him, but he was ware of me,
And drew into the thicket of the wood:
I noting his affections by mine own,
That most are busied when they are most alone,
Pursued my honour, not pursuing his.

sp.speaker: Mou.
sp.l: Black and portentous must this honour prove,
Unless good counsel do the cause remove.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Why tell me Uncle do you know the cause?

sp.speaker: Mou.
sp.l: I neither know it nor can learn of him.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: See where he is, but stand you both aside,
I will know his grievance, or be much denied.

sp.speaker: Mou.
sp.l: I would thou wert so happy by thy stay
To hear true shrift. Come Madam let us away.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Good morrow Cousin.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Is the day so young?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: But new stroke nine.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Ay me, sad hopes seem long.
Was that my Father that went hence so fast?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: It was, what sorrow lengthens Romeos hours?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Not having that, which having makes them short.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: In love.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Out.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Of love.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Out of her favour where I am in love.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Alas that love so gentle in her view,
Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Alas that love whose view is muffled still,
Should without laws give path-ways to our will:
Where shall we dine? Gods me, what fray was here?
Yet tell me not for I have heard it all,
Here is much to do with hate, but more with love.
Why then, O brawling love, O loving hate,
O anything, of nothing first create!
O heavy lightness serious vanity!
Misshapen Chaos of best seeming things,
Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire, sick health,
Still waking sleep, that is not what it is:
This love feel I, which feel no love in this.
Doest thou not laugh?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: No Cuz I rather weep.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Good hart at what?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: At thy good hearts oppression.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Why such is love's transgression,
Griefs of mine own lie heavy at my hart,
Which thou wouldst propagate to have them pressed
With more of thine, this grief that thou hast shown,
Doth add more grief to too much of mine own:
Love is a smoke raised with the fume of sighs
Being purged, a fire sparkling in lovers' eyes:
Being vexed, a sea raging with a lover's tears.
What is it else? A madness most discreet,
A choking gall, and a preserving sweet. Farewell Cuz.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Nay I will go along.
And if you hinder me you do me wrong.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Tut I have lost myself I am not here,
This is not Romeo, he is some other where.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Tell me in sadness whom she is you love?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: What shall I groan and tell thee?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Why no, but sadly tell me who.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Bid a sick man in sadness make his will.
Ah word ill urged to one that is so ill.
In sadness Cousin I do love a woman.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I aimed so right, when as you said you loved.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: A right good mark-man, and she is fair I love.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: A right fair mark fair Cuz is soonest hit.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: But in that hit you miss, she will not be hit
With Cupids arrow, she hath Dianaes wit,
And in strong proof of chastity well armed:
Gainst Cupids childish bow she lives unharmed,
She will not abide the siege of loving terms,
Nor ope her lap to Saint seducing gold,
Ah she is rich in beauty, only poor,
That when she dies with beauty dies her store.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Of honourable reckoning are they both,
And pity it is they live at odds so long:
But leaving that, what say you to my suit?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: What should I say more than I said before,
My daughter is a stranger in the world,
She hath not yet attained to fourteen years:
Let two more summers wither in their pride,
Before she can be thought fit for a Bride.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Younger than she are happy mothers made.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: But too soon marred are these so early married:
But woo her gentle Paris, get her heart,
My word to her consent is but a part.
This night I hold an old accustomed Feast,
Whereto I have invited many a guest,
Such as I love: yet you among the store,
One more most welcome makes the number more.
At my poor house you shall behold this night,
Earth treading stars, that make dark heaven light:
Such comfort as do lusty young men feel,
When well apparelled April on the heel
Of lumping winter treads, even such delights
Amongst fresh female buds shall you this night
Inherit at my house, hear all, all see,
And like her most, whose merit most shall be.
Such amongst view of many mine being one,
May stand in number through in reckoning none.
Where are you sirrah, go trudge about
Through fair Verona streets, and seek them out:
Whose names are written here and to them say,
My house and welcome at their pleasure stay.

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p:
Seek them out whose names are written here,
and yet I know not who are written here: I must to
the learned to learn of them, that is as much to say, as
the Taylor must meddle with his Last, the Shoemaker
with his needle, the Painter with his nets, and the Fisher
with his Pencil, I must to the learned.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Tut man one fire burns out another's burning,
One pain is lessened with another's anguish:
Turn backward, and be holp with backward turning,
One desperate grief cures with another's languish.
Take thou some new infection to thy eye,
And the rank poison of the old will die.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Your Plantain leaf is excellent for that.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: For your broken shin.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Why Romeo art thou mad?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Not mad, but bound more than a mad man is.
Shut up in prison, kept without my food,
Whipped and tormented, and Godden good fellow.

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p: Godgigoden, I pray sir can you read,

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Aye mine own fortune in my misery.

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p:
Perhaps you have learned it without book:
but I pray can you read anything you see?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Aye if I know the letters and the language.

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p: Ye say honestly, rest you merry.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Stay fellow I can read.
Seignior Martino and his wife and daughters, County
Anselme and his beauteous sisters, the Lady widow of
Vtruuio, Seignior Placentio, and his lovely Nieces,
Mercutio and his brother Valentine, mine uncle Capulet his wife and daughters, my fair Niece Rosaline and
Liuia, Seignior Valentio and his Cousin Tibalt, Lucio
and the lively Hellena.
A fair assembly, whither should they come?

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p: Up.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Whither to supper?

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p: To our house.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Whose house?

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p: My Masters.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Indeed I should have asked thee that before.

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p:
Now I will tell you without asking. My Master is
the great rich Capulet, and if you be not of the house of
Mountagues, I pray come and crush a cup of wine. Rest
you merry.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: At this same ancient feast of Capulets,
Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so loves:
With all the admired beauties of Verona,
Go thither and with untainted eye,
Compare her face with some that I shall show,
And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: When the devout religion of mine eye
Maintains such falsehood, then turn tears to fire,
And these who often drowned could never die,
Transparent Heretics be burnt for liars
One fairer than my love, the all seeing sun
Never saw her match, since first the world begun.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Tut you saw her fair none else being by,
Herself poised with herself in either eye:
But in that Crystal scales let there be weighed,
Your Lady's love, against some other maid
That I will show you shining at this feast,
And she shall scant show well that now seems best.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I will go along no such sight to be shown,
But to rejoice in splendour of mine own.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Nurse where is my daughter call her forth to
me.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Now by my maiden head at twelve year old I
bad her come, what Lamb, what Lady bird, God forbid.
Where is this girl? what Iuliet.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: How now who calls?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Your Mother.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Madam I am here, what is your will?

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: This is the matter. Nurse give leave a while, we
must talk in secret. Nurse come back again I have remembered me, thou shalt hear our counsel. Thou know
est my daughters of a pretty age.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Faith I can tell her age unto a hour.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: She is not fourteen.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
I will lay fourteen of my teeth, and yet to my
teen be it spoken, I have but four, she is not fourteen.
How long is it now to Lammas-tide?

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: A fortnight and odd days.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Even or odd, of all days in the year come
Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen. Susan and she
God rest all Christian souls were of an age. Well Susan is

with God, she was too good for me: But as I said on Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen, that shall she marry I remember it well. It is since the Earth-quake now eleven years, and she was wend I never shall forget it, of
all the days of the year upon that day: for I had then laid
wormwood to my dug, sitting in the sun under the Dove house-wall. My Lord and you were then at Mantua, nay I
do bear a brain: But as I said, when it did taste the wormwood on the nipple of my dug, and felt it bitter, pretty fool
to see it tetchy and fall out with Dug. Shake quoth the
Dove-house it was no need I trow to bid me trudge, and since
that time it is eleven year: for then could Iuliet stand
high lone, nay by the Rood, she could have waddled up and
down, for even the day before she brake her brow, and then
my husband God be with his soul, he was a merry man:
Dost thou fall forward Iuliet? thou wilt fall backward when
thou hast more wit: wilt thou not Iuliet? and by my hollidame, the pretty fool left crying and said I. To see how a
jest shall come about, I warrant you if I should live a hundred year, I never should forget it, wilt thou not Iuliet?
and by my troth she stinted and cried I.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And stint thou too, I prithee Nurse say I.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Well go thy ways, God mark thee for his
grace, thou wert the prettiest Babe that ever I nursed, might
I but live to see thee married once, I have my wish.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: And that same marriage Nurse, is the Theme
I meant to talk of: Tell me Iuliet, how stand you affected to be married:

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: It is an honour that I dream not of.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: An honour! were not I thy only Nurse, I
would say thou hadst sucked wisdom from thy Teat.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Well girl, the Noble County Paris seeks
thee for his Wife.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: A man young Lady, Lady such a man as all
the world, why he is a man of wax.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Veronaes Summer hath not such a flower

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Nay he is a flower, in faith a very flower.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Well Iuliet, how like you of Paris love.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I will look to like, if looking liking move,
But no more deep will I engage mine eye,
Than your consent gives strength to make it fly.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Madam you are called for, supper is ready,
the Nurse cursed in the Pantry, all things in extremity,
make haste for I must be gone to wait.

stage.l: Enter Maskers with Romeo and a Page.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: What shall this speech be spoke for our excuse?
Or shall we on without Apology.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: The date is out of such prolixity,
We will have no Cupid hoodwinked with a Scarf,
Bearing a Tartars painted bow of lath,
Scaring the Ladies like a crow-keeper:
Nor no without book Prologue faintly spoke
After the Prompter, for our entrance.
But let them measure us by what they will,
We will measure them a measure and be gone.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: A torch for me I am not for this ambling,
Being but heavy I will bear the light.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Believe me Romeo I must have you dance.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Not I believe me you have dancing shoes
With nimble soles, I have a soul of lead
So stakes me to the ground I cannot stir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Give me a case to put my visage in,
A visor for a visor, what care I
What curious eye doth coat deformity.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Give me a Torch, let wantons light of hart
Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels:
For I am proverbed with a Grandsire phrase,
I will be a candleholder and look on,
The game was never so fair and I am done.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Tut dun is the mouse, the Constable's old word,
If thou beest Dun, we will draw thee from the mire
Of this sir-reverence love wherein thou stickest.
Leave this talk, we burn day light here.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Nay that is not so.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I mean sir in delay,
We burn our lights by night, like Lamps by day,
Take our good meaning for our judgment sits
Three times a day, ere once in her right wits.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: So we mean well by going to this masque:
But it is no wit to go.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why Romeo may one ask?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I dreamt a dream tonight.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And so did I.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Why what was yours?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That dreamers often lie.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: In bed a sleep while they do dream things true.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Ah then I see Queen Mab hath been with you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Queen Mab what is she?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: She is the Fairies Midwife and doth come
In shape no bigger than an Agate stone
On the forefinger of a Burgomaster,
Drawn with a team of little Atomi,
Athwart men's noses when they lie asleep.
Her waggon spokes are made of spinners webs,
The cover, of the wings of Grasshoppers,
The traces are the Moonshine watery beams,
The collars crickets bones, the lash of films,
Her waggoner is a small gray coated fly,
Not half so big as is a little worm,
Picked from the lazy finger of a maid,
And in this sort she gallops up and down
Through Lovers' brains, and then they dream of love:
Over Courtiers knees: who strait on curtsies dream
Over Ladies lips, who dream on kisses strait:
Which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues,
Because their breathes with sweetmeats tainted are:
Sometimes she gallops ore a Lawyer's lap,
And then dreams he of smelling out a suit,
And sometime comes she with a tithe pigs tail,
Tickling a Parsons nose that lies asleep,
And then dreams he of another benefice:
Sometime she gallops ore a soldier's nose,
And then dreams he of cutting foreign throats,
Of breaches ambuscados, countermines,
Of healths five fathom deep, and then anon
Drums in his ear: at which he starts and wakes,
And swears a Prayer or two and sleeps again.
This is that Mab that makes maids lie on their backs,
And proves them women of good carriage.
This is the very Mab that plaits the manes of Horses in the night,
And plaits the Elf-locks in foul sluttish hair,
Which once untangled much misfortune breeds.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Peace, peace, thou talkest of nothing.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: True I talk of dreams,
Which are the Children of an idle brain,
Begot of nothing but vain fantasy,
Which is as thin a substance as the air,
And more inconstant than the wind,
Which woos even now the frozen bowels of the north,
And being angered puffs away in haste,
Turning his face to the dew-dropping south.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Come, come, this wind doth blow us from ourselves.
Supper is done and we shall come too late.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I fear too early, for my mind misgives
Some consequence is hanging in the stars,
Which bitterly begins his fearful date
With this nights revels, and expires the term
Of a despised life, closed in this breast,
By some untimely forfeit of vile death:
But he that hath the steerage of my course
Directs my sail, on lusty Gentlemen.

stage.l: Enter old Capulet with the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Welcome Gentlemen, welcome Gentlemen,
Ladies that have their toes unplagued with Corns
Will have about with you, ah ha my Mistresses,
Which of you all will now refuse to dance?
She that makes dainty, she I will swear hath Corns.
Am I come near you now, welcome Gentlemen, welcome,
More lights you knaues, and turn these tables up,
And quench the fire the room is grown too hot.
Ah sirrah, this unlooked for sport comes well,
Nay sit, nay sit, good Cousin Capulet:
For you and I are past our standing days,
How long is it since you and I were in a Masque?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: By Lady sir it is thirty years at least.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: It is not so much, it is not so much.
It is since the marriage of Lucentio,
Come Pentecost as quickly as it will,
Some five and twenty years, and then we masked.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: It is more, it is more, his son is elder far.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Will you tell me that it cannot be so,
His son was but a Ward three years ago,
Good youths I faith. O youth is a jolly thing.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: What Lady is that that doth enrich the hand
Of yonder Knight? O she doth teach the torches to
burn bright!
It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night,
Like a rich jewel in an Aethiops ear,
Beauty too rich for use, for earth too dear:
So shines a snow-white Swan trouping with Crows,
As this fair Lady over her fellows shows.
The measure done, I will watch her place of stand,
And touching hers, make happy my rude hand
Did my heart love till now? Forswear it sight,
I never saw true beauty till this night.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: This by his voice should be a Mountague,
Fetch me my rapier boy. What dares the slave
Come hither covered with an Antic face,
To scorn and jeer at our solemnity?
Now by the stock and honour of my kin,
To strike him dead I hold it for no sin.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why how now Cousin, wherefore storm you so.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Uncle this is a Mountague our foe,
A villain that is hither come in spite,
To mock at our solemnity this night.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Young Romeo, is it not?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: It is that villain Romeo.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Let him alone, he bears him like a portly gentleman,
And to speak truth, Verona brags of him,
As of a virtuous and well governed youth:
I would not for the wealth of all this town,
Here in my house do him disparagement:
Therefore be quiet take no note of him,
Bear a fair presence, and put off these frowns,
An ill beseeming semblance for a feast.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: It fits when such a villain is a guest,
I will not endure him.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: He shall be endured, go to I say, he shall,
Am I the Master of the house or you?
You will not endure him? God shall mend my soul
You will make a mutiny amongst my guests,
You will set cock-a-hoop, You will be the man.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Uncle it is a shame.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Go too, you are a saucy knave.
This trick will scathe you one day I know what.
Well said my hearts. Be quiet:
More light Ye knave, or I will make you quiet.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Patience perforce with with full choler meeting.
Makes my flesh tremble in their different greetings:
I will withdraw, but this intrusion shall
Now seeming sweet, convert to bitter gall.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: If I profane with my unworthy hand,
This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this:
My lips two blushing Pilgrims ready stand,
To smooth the rough touch with a gentle kiss.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Good Pilgrim you do wrong your hand too much,
Which mannerly devotion shows in this:
For Saints have hands which holy Palmers touch,
And Palm to Palm is holy Palmers kiss.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Have not Saints lips, and holy Palmers too?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Yes Pilgrim lips that they must use in prayer.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Why then fair saint, let lips do what hands do,
They pray, yield thou, least faith turn to despair.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Saints do not move though: grant nor prayer
forsake.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Then move not till my prayers effect I take.
Thus from my lips, by yours my sin is purged.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Then have my lips the sin that they have took.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Sin from my lips, O trespass sweetly urged!
Give me my sin again.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: You kiss by the book.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Madam your mother calls.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: What is her mother?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Marry Bachelor her mother is the Lady of the
house, and a good Lady, and a wise, and a virtuous. I nursed
her daughter that you talked withal, I tell you, he that can
lay hold of her shall have the chinks.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Is she a Mountague? O dear account,
My life is my foes thrall.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Nay gentlemen prepare not to be gone,
We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.
I pray you let me entreat you. Is it so?
Well then I thank you honest Gentlemen,
I promise you but for your company,
I would have been a bed an hour ago:
Light to my chamber ho.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Nurse, what is yonder Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: The son and heir of old Tiberio.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What is he that now is going out of door?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: That as I think is young Petruchio.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What is he that follows there that would not dance?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Go learn his name, if he be married,
My grave is like to be my wedding bed.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: His name is Romeo and a Mountague, the only
son of your great enemy.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: My only Love sprung from my only hate,
Too early seen unknown, and known too late:
Prodigious birth of love is this to me,
That I should love a loathed enemy.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: What is this? what is that?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Nothing Nurse but a rime I learnt even now of
one I danced with.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Come your mother stays for you, I will go a long
with you.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Shall I go forward and my heart is here?
Turn back dull earth and find thy Centre out.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Romeo, my cousin Romeo.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Doest thou hear he is wise,
Upon my life he hath stolen him home to bed.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: He came this way, and leapt this Orchard wall.
Call good Mercutio.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Call, nay I will conjure too.
Romeo, madman, humours, passion, liver, appear thou in
likeness of a sigh: speak but one rime and I am satisfied, cry
but ay me. Pronounce but Love and Dove, speak to
my gossip Venus one fair word, one nickname for her
purblind son and heir young Abraham: Cupid he
that shot so trim when young King Cophetua loved the
beggar wench. He hears me not. I conjure thee by
Rosalindes bright eye, high forehead, and scarlet lip, her
pretty foot, straight leg, and quivering thigh, and the
domains that there adjacent lie , that in thy likeness
thou appear to us.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: If he do hear thee thou wilt anger him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Tut this cannot anger him, marry if one should
raise a spirit in his Mistress circle of some strange fashion,
making it there to stand till she had laid it, and conjured
it down, that were some spite. My invocation is fair
and honest, and in his Mistress name I conjure only but
to raise up him.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Well he hath hid himself amongst those trees,
To be comforted with the humorous night,
Blind in his love, and best befits the dark.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: If love be blind, love will not hit the mark,
Now will he sit under a Medlar tree,
And wish his Mistress were that kind of fruit,
As maids call Medlars when they laugh alone.
Ah Romeo that she were, ah that she were
An open Et cetera, thou a poprin Pear.
Romeo God night, I will to my trundle bed:
This field bed is too cold for me.
Come let us away, for it is but vain,
To seek him here that means not to be found.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: He jests at scars that never felt a wound:
But soft, what light forth yonder window breaks?
It is the East, and Iuliet is the Sun,
Arise fair Sun, and kill the envious Moon
That is already sick, and pale with grief:
That thou her maid, art far more fair than she.
Be not her maid since she is envious,
Her vestal livery is but pale and green,
And none but fools do wear it, cast it off.
She speaks, but she says nothing. What of that?
Her eye discourseth, I will answer it.
I am too bold, it is not to me she speaks,
Two of the fairest stars in all the skies,
Having some business, do entreat her eyes
To twinkle in their spheres till they return.
What if her eyes were there, they in her head,
The brightness of her cheeks would shame those stars:
As day-light doth a Lamp, her eyes in heaven,
Would through the airy region stream so bright,
That birds would sing, and think it were not night.
O now she leans her cheeks upon her hand,
I would I were the glove to that same hand,
That I might kiss that cheek.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ay me.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: She speaks, O speak again bright Angel:
For thou art as glorious to this night being over my head,
As is a winged messenger of heaven
Unto the white upturned wondering eyes,
Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him,
When he bestrides the lazy pacing clouds,
and sails upon the bosom of the air.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ah Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thou Romeo?
Deny thy Father, and refuse thy name,
Or if thou wilt not be but sworn my love,
And I will no longer be a Capulet.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Shall I hear more, or shall I speak to this?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: It is but thy name that is mine enemy.
What is Mountague? It is nor hand nor foot,
Nor arm, nor face, nor any other part.
What is in a name? That which we call a Rose,
By any other name would smell as sweet:
So Romeo would, were he not Romeo called,
Retain the divine perfection he owes:
Without that title Romeo part thy name,
And for that name which is no part of thee,
Take all I have.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I take thee at thy word,
Call me but love, and I will be new Baptised,
Henceforth I never will be Romeo.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What man art thou, that thus bescreened in night,
Doest stumble on my counsel?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: By a name I know not how to tell thee.
My name dear Saint is hateful to myself,
Because it is an enemy to thee.
Had I it written I would tear the word.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words
Of that tongues utterance, yet I know the sound:
Art thou not Romeo and a Mountague?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Neither fair Saint, if either thee displease.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: How camest thou hither, tell me and wherefore?
The Orchard walls are high and hard to clime,
And the place death considering who thou art,
If any of my kinsmen find thee here.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: By love's light wings did I overperch these walls,
For stony limits cannot hold love out,
And what love can do, that dares love attempt,
Therefore thy kinsmen are no let to me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: If they do find thee they will murder thee.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Alas there lies more peril in thine eyes,
Then twenty of their swords, look thou but sweet,
And I am proof against their enmity.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I would not for the world they should find thee here.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I have nights cloak to hide thee from their sight,
And but thou love me let them find me here:
For life were better ended by their hate,
Than death prorogued wanting of thy love.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: By whose directions foundest thou out this place.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: By love, who first did prompt me to enquire,
I he gave me counsel and I lent him eyes.
I am no Pilot: yet wert thou as far
As that vast shore, washed with the furthest sea,
I would adventure for such Merchandise.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Thou knowest the mask of night is on my face,
Else would a Maiden blush bepaint my cheeks:
For that which thou haste heard me speak tonight,
Fain would I dwell on form, fain fain deny,
What I have spoke: but farewell complements.
Doest thou love me? Nay I know thou wilt say I,
And I will take thy word: but if thou swearest,
Thou mayst prove false:
At Lovers' perjuries they say Jove smiles.
Ah gentle Romeo, if thou love pronounce it faithfully:
Or if thou think I am too easily won,
I will frown and say thee nay and be perverse,
So thou wilt woo: but else not for the world,
In truth fair Mountague, I am too fond,
And therefore thou mayst think my behaviour light:
But trust me gentleman I will prove more true,
Than they that have more cunning to be strange.
I should have been strange I must confess,
But that thou over-heardst ere I was ware
My true love's Passion: therefore pardon me,
And not impute this yielding to light love,
Which the dark night hath so discovered.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: By yonder blessed Moon I swear,
That tips with silver all these fruit trees tops.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O swear not by the Moon the unconstant Moon,
That monthly changeth in her circled orb,
Least that thy love prove likewise variable.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Now by

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Nay do not swear at all,
Or if thou swear, swear by thy glorious self,
Which art the God of my Idolatry,
And I will believe thee.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: If my true heart's love

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Swear not at all, though I do joy in thee
I have small joy in this contract tonight,
It is too rash, too sudden, too unadvised,
Too like the lightning that doth cease to be
Ere one can say it lightens. I hear some coming,
Dear love adieu, sweet Mountague be true,
Stay but a little and I will come again.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: O blessed blessed night, I fear being night,
All this is but a dream I hear and see,
Too flattering true to be substantial.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Three words good Romeo and good night indeed.
If that thy bent of love be honourable?
Thy purpose marriage, send me word tomorrow
By one that I will procure to come to thee:
Where and what time thou wilt perform that right,
And all my fortunes at thy foot I will lay,
And follow thee my Lord through out the world.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Love goes toward love like school boys from
their books,
But love from love, to school with heavy looks.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Romeo, Romeo, O for a falconer's voice,
To lure this Tassel gentle back again:
Bondage is hoarse and may not cry aloud,
Else would I tear the Cave where Echo lies
And make her airy voice as hoarse as mine,
With repetition of my Romeos name.
Romeo?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: It is my soul that calls upon my name,
How silver sweet sound lovers' tongues in night.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Romeo?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: At what o'clock tomorrow shall I send?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: At the hour of nine.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I will not fail, it is twenty years till then.
Romeo I have forgot why I did call thee back.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Let me stay here till you remember it.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I shall forget to have thee still stay here,
Remembering how I love thy company.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: And I will stay still to have thee still forget,
Forgetting any other home but this.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: It is almost morning I would have thee gone,
But yet no further then a wantons bird,
Who let us it hop a little from her hand,
Like a pore prisoner in his twisted gives,
And with a silk thread pulls it back again,
Too loving jealous of his liberty.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Would I were thy bird.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Sweet so would I,
Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing thee.
Good night, good night, parting is such sweet sorrow,
That I shall say good night till it be morrow.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace on thy breast.
I would that I were sleep and peace of sweet to rest.
Now will I go to my Ghostly fathers Cell,
His help to crave, and my good hap to tell.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: The gray eyed morn smiles on the frowning night,
Checkering the Eastern clouds with streaks of light,
And flecked darkness like a drunkard reels,
From forth day's path, and Titans fiery wheels:
Now ere the Sun advance his burning eye,
The world to cheer, and nights dark dew to dry
We must up fill this osier Cage of ours,
With baleful weeds, and precious juiced flowers.
O mickle is the powerful grace that lies
In herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities:
For nought so vile, that vile on earth doth live,
But to the earth some special good doth give:
Nor nought so good, but strained from that fair use,
Revolts to vice and stumbles on abuse:
Vertue itself turns vice being misapplied,
And vice sometimes by action dignified.
Within the infant rind of this small flower,
Poison hath residence, and medicine power:
For this being smelt too, with that part cheers each hart,
Being tasted slays all senses with the hart.
Two such opposed foes encamp them still,
In man as well as herbs, grace and rude will,
And where the worser is predominant,
Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Good morrow to my Ghostly Confessor.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Benedicite, what early tongue so soon saluteth me?
Young son it argues a distempered head,
So soon to bid good morrow to my bed.
Care keeps his watch in every old man's eye,
And where care lodgeth, sleep can never lie:
But where unbruised youth with unstuffed brains
Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep remains:
Therefore thy earliness doth me assure,
Thou art uprowsed by some distemperature.
Or if not so, then here I hit it right
Our Romeo hath not been a bed tonight.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: The last was true, the sweeter rest was mine.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: God pardon sin, wert thou with Rosaline?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: With Rosaline my Ghostly father no,
I have forgot that name, and that names woe.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: That is my good son: but where hast thou been then?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I tell thee ere thou ask it me again,
I have been feasting with mine enemy:
Where on the sudden one hath wounded me
That is by me wounded, both our remedies
With in thy help and holy physic lies,
I bear no hatred blessed man : for lo
My intercession likewise steads my foe.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Be plain my son and homely in thy drift,
Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Then plainly know my heart's dear love is set
On the fair daughter of rich Capulet:
As mine on hers, so hers likewise on mine,
And all combined, save what thou must combine
By holy marriage: where, and when,and how,
We met, we wooed, and made exchange of vows,
I will tell thee as I pass: But this I pray,
That thou consent to marry us today.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Holy Saint. Francis, what a change is here?
Is Rosaline whom thou didst love so dear
So soon forsook, lo young men's love then lies
Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.
Iesu Maria, what a deal of brine
Hath washed thy sallow cheeks for Rosaline?
How much salt water cast away in waste,
To season love, that of love doth not taste.
The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears,
Thy old groans ring yet in my ancient ears,
And lo upon thy cheek the stain doth sit,
Of an old tear that is not washed off yet.
If ever thou wert thus, and these woes thine,
Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline,
And art thou changed, pronounce this sentence then
Women may fall, when there is no strength in men.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Thou chidest me oft for loving Rosaline.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: For doting, not for loving, pupil mine.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: And badest me bury love.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Not in a grave,
To lay one in another out to have.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I prithee chide not, she whom I love now
Doth grace for grace, and love for love allow:
The other did not so.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: O she knew well
Thy love did read by rote, and could not spell,
But come young Waverer, come go with me,
In one respect I will thy assistant be:
For this alliance may so happy prove,
To turn your Households' rancour to pure love.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Why what is become of Romeo? came he not
home tonight?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Not to his Fathers, I spake with his man.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Ah that same pale hard hearted wench, that Rosaline
Torments him so, that he will sure run mad.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Tybalt the Kinsman of old Capolet
Hath sent a Letter to his Fathers House:

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Some Challenge on my life.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Romeo will answer it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Aye, any man that can write may answer a letter.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Nay, he will answer the letters master if he be
challenged.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Who, Romeo? why he is already dead: stabbed
with a white wenches black eye, shot thorough the ear
with a love song, the very pin of his heart cleft with the
blind bow-boys butt-shaft. And is he a man to encounter
Tybalt?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Why what is Tybalt?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
More than the prince of cats I can tell you. O
he is the courageous captain of complements. Catso, he
fights as you sing pricksong , keeps time distance and
proportion, rests me his minim rest one two and the third
in your bosom, the very butcher of a silken button, a Duel list a Duellist, a gentleman of the very first house of the first
and second cause, ah the immortal Passado, the Punto reuerso, the Hay.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: The what?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
The Pox of such limping antique affecting fantasticos these new tuners of accents. By Iesu a very good
blade, a very tall man, a very good whore. Why grand sir is not this a miserable case that we should be still afflicted
with these strange flies: these fashion-mongers, these pardon-mes, that stand so much on the new form, that they
cannot sit at ease on the old bench. O their bones, their
bones.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Here comes Romeo.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Without his Roe, like a dried Herring. O flesh flesh
how art thou fishified. Sirrah now is he for the numbers that
Petrarch flowed in : Laura to his Lady was but a kitchen
drudge, yet she had a better love to berime her: Dido a dowdy Cleopatra a Gypsy, Hero and Hellen hildings and harlotries: Thisbie a gray eye or so, but not to the purpose. Signior
Romeo bon iour, there is a French courtesy to your French
stop: ye gave us the counterfeit fairly yesternight.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: What counterfeit I pray you?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: The slip the slip, can you not conceive?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p:
I cry you mercy my business was great, and in such
a case as mine, a man may strain courtesy.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
O that is as much to say as such a case as yours will
constrain a man to bow in the hams.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: A most courteous exposition.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why I am the very pink of courtesy.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Pink for flower?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Then is my Pump well flowered:

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Well said, follow me now that jest till thou hast
worn out thy Pump, that when the single sole of it is worn
the jest may remain after the wearing solely singular.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: O single soled jest solely singular for the singleness.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Come between us good Benuolio, for my wits fail.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Swits and spurs, swits and spurs, or I will cry a match.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Nay if thy wits run the wild goose chase, I have
done: for I am sure thou hast more of the goose in one of
thy wits, than I have in all my five: Was I with you there for
the goose?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p:
Thou wert never with me for any thing, when
thou wert not with me for the goose.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I will bite thee by the ear for that jest.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Nay good goose bite not.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why thy wit is a bitter sweeting, a most sharp sauce

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: And was it not well served in to a sweet goose?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
O here is a wit of Cheverel that stretcheth
from an inch narrow to an ell broad.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p:
I stretched it out for the word broad, which added to
the goose, proves thee fair and wide a broad goose.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Why is not this better now than groaning for love?
why now art thou sociable, now art thou thyself, now art
thou what thou art, as well by art as nature. This drivelling
love is like a great natural, that runs up and down to hide
his babble in a hole.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Stop there.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Why thou wouldst have me stop my tale against
the hair.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Thou wouldst have made thy tale too long?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Tut man thou art deceived, I meant to make it
short, for I was come to the whole depth of my tale? and
meant indeed to occupy the argument no longer.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Here is goodly gear.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: A sail, a sail, a sail.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Two, two, a shirt and a smock.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Peter, prithee give me my fan.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
prithee do good Peter, to hide her face: for
her fan is the fairer of the two.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: God ye good morrow Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: God ye good even fair Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Is it god ye good even I pray you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
It is no less I assure you, for the bawdy hand of
the dial is even now upon the prick of noon.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Fie, what a man is this?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p:
A Gentleman Nurse, that God hath made for
himself to mar.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
By my troth well said : for himself to mar
quoth he? I pray you can any of you tell where one may
find young Romeo?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p:
I can : but young Romeo will be elder when you
have found him, than he was when you sought him, I am
the youngest of that name for fault of a worse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Well said.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yea, is the worst well? mass well noted, wisely, wisely.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: If you be he sir, I desire some conference with ye.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: O, belike she means to invite him to supper.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: So ho. A bawd, a bawd, a bawd.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Why what hast found man?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
No hare sir, unless it be a hare in a lenten pie,
that is somewhat stale and hoar ere it be eaten.
He walks by them, and sings.
And an old hare hoar, and an old hare hoar
is very good meat in Lent:
But a hare that is hoar is too much for a score,
if it hoar ere it be spent.
You will come to your fathers to supper?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Farewell ancient Lady, farewell sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
Marry farewell. Pray what saucy merchant was
this that was so full of his rope-ripe?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p:
A gentleman Nurse that loves to hear himself
talk, and will speak more in an hour than he will stand
to in a month.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
If he stand to any thing against me, I will take
him down if he were lustier than he is: if I cannot take him
down, I will find them that shall: I am none of his flirt-gills, I am none of his skeans-mates.

stage.l: She turnes to Peter her man.

sp.p:
And thou like a knave must stand by, and see every Iacke
use me at his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
I see nobody use you at his pleasure, if I had, I
would soon have drawn: you know my tool is as soon
out as another's if I see time and place.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
Now afore God he hath so vexed me, that every
member about me quivers: scurvy Iacke. But as I said, my
Lady bad me seek ye out, and what she bad me tell ye,
that I will keep to myself: but if you should lead her into a
fools' paradise as they say, it were a very gross kind of
behaviour as they say, for the Gentlewoman is young. Now
if you should deal doubly with her, it were very weak
dealing, and not to be offered to any Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Nurse, commend me to thy Lady, tell her I protest.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
Goodheart: yfaith I will tell her so: o she will be
a joyful woman.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Why, what wilt thou tell her?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
That you do protest: which (as I take it) is a
Gentleman-like proffer.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Bid her get leave tomorrow morning
To come to shrift to Friar Laurence cell:
And stay thou Nurse behind the Abbey wall,
My man shall come to thee, and bring along
The cords, made like a tackled stair,
Which to the hightop-gallant of my joy
Must be my conduct in the secret night.
Hold, take that for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: No, not a penny truly.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I say you shall not choose.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Well, tomorrow morning she shall not fail.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Farewell, be trusty, and I will quite thy pain.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Peter, take my fan, and go before.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: The clock stroke nine when I did send my Nurse
In half an hour she promised to return.
Perhaps she cannot find him. That is not so.
O she is lazy, Love's heralds should be thoughts,
And run more swift, than hasty powder fired,
Doth hurry from the fearful Cannons mouth.
O now she comes. Tell me gentle Nurse,
What says my Love?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: O I am weary, let me rest a while. Lord how
my bones ache. O where is my man? Give me some aqua vitae.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I would thou hadst my bones, and I thy news.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Fie, what a jaunt have I had: and my back on tother side. Lord, Lord, what a case am I in.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: But tell me sweet Nurse, what says Romeo?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
Romeo, nay, alas you cannot choose a man. He is
nobody, he is not the Flower of courtesy, he is not a proper
man: and for a hand, and a foot, and a bawdy, well go thy
way wench, thou hast it ifaith, Lord, Lord, how my head
beats?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What of all this? tell me what says he to our marriage?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Marry he says like an honest Gentleman, and a
kind, and I warrant a virtuous : wheres your Mother?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Lord, Lord, how oddly thou replyest? He says like a
kind Gentleman, and an honest, and a virtuous; wheres
your mother?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Marry come up, cannot you stay a while? is this
the poultice for mine aching bones? next arrant you will have
done, even do it yourself.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Nay stay sweet Nurse, I do entreat thee now,
What says my Love, my Lord, my Romeo?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Go, hie you straight to Friar Laurence Cell,
and frame a scuse that you must go to shrift:
There stays a Bridegroom to make you a Bride.
Now comes the wanton blood up in your cheeks,
I must provide a ladder made of cords,
With which your Lord must clime a bird's nest soon.
I must take pains to further your delight,
But you must bear the burden soon at night.
Doth this news please you now?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: How doth her latter words revive my hart.
Thanks gentle Nurse, dispatch thy business,
And I will not fail to meet my Romeo.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Now Father Laurence, in thy holy grant
Consists the good of me and Iuliet.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Without more words I will do all I may,
To make you happy if in me it lie.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: This morning here she pointed we should meet,
And consummate those never parting bands,
Witness of our hearts' love by joining hands,
And come she will.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: I guess she will indeed,
Youths love is quick, swifter than swiftest speed.

stage.l: Enter Iuliet somewhat fast, and embraceth Romeo.

sp.l: See where she comes.
So light of foot never hurts the trodden flower:
Of love and joy, see see the sovereign power.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Romeo.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: My Iuliet welcome. As do waking eyes
(Closed in Nights mists) attend the frolic Day,
So Romeo hath expected Iuliet,
And thou art come.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I am (if I be Day)
Come to my Sun: shine forth, and make me fair.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: All beauteous fairness dwelleth in thine eyes.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Romeo from thine all brightness doth arise.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Come wantons, come, the stealing hours do pass
Defer embracements till some fitter time,
Part for a while, you shall not be alone,
Till holy Church have joined ye both in one.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Lead holy Father, all delay seems long.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Make haste, make haste, this lingering doth us wrong.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: O, soft and fair makes sweetest work they say.
Haste is common hinderer in cross way.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I prithee good Mercutio let us retire,
The day is hot, the Capels are abroad.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Thou art like one of those, that when he comes
into the confines of a tavern, claps me his rapier on the
board, and says, God send me no need of thee: and by
the operation of the next cup of wine, he draws it on the
drawer, when indeed there is no need.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Am I like such a one?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Go too, thou art as hot a Iacke being moved,
and as soon moved to be moody, and as soon moody to
be moved.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: And what too?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Nay, and there were two such, we should have
none shortly. Didst not thou fall out with a man for cracking of nuts, having no other reason, but because thou hadst
hazel eyes? what eye but such an eye would have picked out
such a quarrel? With another for coughing, because he
waked thy dog that lay a sleep in the Sun ? With a
Taylor for wearing his new doublet before Easter: and
with another for tying his new shoes with old ribands.
And yet thou wilt forbid me of quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: By my head here comes a Capolet.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: By my heel I care not.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Gentlemen a word with one of you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: But one word with one of us? You had best couple
it with somewhat,and make it a word and a blow.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: I am apt enough to that if I have occasion.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Could you not take occasion?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Mercutio thou consorts with Romeo?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Consort Zwounes consort? the slave will make fiddlers of us. If you do sirrah, look for nothing but discord: For
here is my fiddlestick.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Well peace be with you, here comes my man.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But I will be hanged if he wear your livery: Marry
go before into the field, and he may be your follower, so in
that sense your worship may call him man.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Romeo the hate I bear to thee can afford no better words then these, thou art a villain.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Tybalt the love I bear to thee, doth excuse the
appertaining rage to such a word: villain am I none, therefore I well perceive thou knowest me not.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Base boy this cannot serve thy turn, and therefore
draw.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I do protest I never injured thee, but love thee better than thou canst devise, till thou shalt know the reason of
my love.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O dishonourable vile submission. Allastockado caries
it away. You Rat-catcher, come back, come back.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: What wouldst with me?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Nothing King of Cates, but borrow one of your
nine lives, therefore come draw your rapier out of your
scabbard, least mine be about your ears ere you be aware.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p:
Stay Tibalt, hold Mercutio: Benuolio beat
down their weapons.

stage.l: Tibalt under Romeos arme thrusts Mercutio, in and flyes.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Is he gone, hath he nothing? A pox on your
houses.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: What art thou hurt man, the wound is not deep.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
No not so deep as a Well, nor so wide as a
barn door, but it will serve I warrant. What meant you to
come between us? I was hurt under your arm.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: I did all for the best.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
A pox of your houses, I am fairly dressed. Sirrah
go fetch me a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I go my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
I am peppered for this world, I am sped yfaith, he
hath made worms' meat of me, and ye ask for me tomorrow you shall find me a grave-man. A pox of your houses,
I shall be fairly mounted upon four men's shoulders: For
your house of the Mountegues and the Capolets: and then
some patiently rogue, some Sexton, some base slave shall
write my Epitaph, that Tybalt came and broke the Princes
Laws, and Mercutio was slain for the first and second
cause. Where is the Surgeon?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He is come sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Now he will keep a mumbling in my guts on the
other side, come Benuolio, lend me thy hand: a pox of your
houses.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: This Gentleman the Princes near Ally.
My very friend hath taken this mortal wound
In my behalf, my reputation stained
With Tibalts slander, Tybalt that an hour
Hath been my kinsman. Ah Iuliet
Thy beauty makes me thus effeminate,
And in my temper softens valour's steel.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Ah Romeo Romeo brave Mercutio is dead,
That gallant spirit hath aspired the clouds,
Which too untimely scorned the lowly earth.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: This day's black fate,on more days doth depend
This but begins what other days must end.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Here comes the furious Tibalt back again.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: A live in triumph and Mercutio slain?
Away to heaven respective lenity:
And fire-eyed fury be my conduct now.
Now Tibalt take the villain back again,
Which late thou gavest me: for Mercutios soul,
Is but a little way above the clouds,
And stays for thine to bear him company.
Or thou, or I, or both shall follow him.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Romeo away, thou seest that Tibalt's slain,
The Citizens approach, away, begone
Thou wilt be taken.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Ah I am fortunes slave.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Where is he that slew Mercutio, Tybalt that villain?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: There is that Tybalt.
up sirrah go with us.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Where be the vile beginners of this fray?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Ah Noble Prince I can discover all
The most unlucky manage of this brawl.
Here lies the man slain by young Romeo,
That slew thy kinsman brave Mercutio,

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Tibalt, Tybalt, O my brothers child,
Unhappy fight? Ah the blood is spilt
Of my dear kinsman, Prince as thou art true:
For blood of ours, shed blood of Mountagew.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Speak Benuolio who began this fray?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Tibalt here slain whom Romeos hand did slay.
Romeo who spake him fair bid him bethink
How nice the quarrel was.
But Tibalt still persisting in his wrong,
The stout Mercutio drew to calm the storm,
Which Romeo seeing called stay Gentlemen,
And on me cried, who drew to part their strife,
And with his agile arm young Romeo,
As fast as tongue cried peace, sought peace to make.
While they were interchanging thrusts and blows,
Under young Romeos labouring arm to part,
The furious Tybalt cast an envious thrust,
That rid the life of stout Mercutio.
With that he fled, but presently returned,
And with his rapier braved Romeo:
That had but newly entertained revenge,
And ere I could draw forth my rapier
To part their fury, down did Tybalt fall,
And this way Romeo fled.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: He is a Mountagew and speaks partial,
Some twenty of them fought in this black strife:
And all those twenty could but kill one life.
I do entreat sweet Prince thou wilt justice give,
Romeo slew Tybalt, Romeo may not live.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: And for that offence
Immediately we do exile him hence.
I have an interest in your hates proceeding,
My blood for your rude brawls doth lie a bleeding.
But I will amerce you with so large a fine,
That you shall all repent the loss of mine.
I will be deaf to pleading and excuses,
Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase for abuses.
Pity shall dwell and govern with us still:
Mercy to all but murderers, pardoning none that kill.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Gallop apace you fiery footed steeds
To Phœbus mansion, such a Waggoner
As Phaeton, would quickly bring you thither,
And send in cloudy night immediately.

stage.l: Enter Nurse wringing her hands, with the ladder

sp.l: But how now Nurse: O Lord, why lookest thou sad?
What hast thou there, the cords?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Aye, Aye, the cords: alack we are undone,
We are undone, Lady we are undone.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What devil art thou that torments me thus?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Alack the day, he is dead, he is dead, he is dead.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: This torture should be roared in dismal hell.
Can heavens be so envious?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Romeo can if heavens cannot.
I saw the wound, I saw it with mine eyes,
God save the sample, on his manly breast:
A bloody coarse, a piteous bloody coarse,
All pale as ashes, I swooned at the sight.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ah Romeo, Romeo, what disaster hap
Hath severed thee from thy true Iuliet?
Ah why should Heaven so much conspire with Woe,
Or Fate envy our happy Marriage,
So soon to sunder us by timeless Death?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: O Tybalt, Tybalt, the best friend I had,
O honest Tybalt, courteous Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What storm is this that blows so contrary,
Is Tybalt dead, and Romeo murdered:
My dear loved cousin, and my dearest Lord.
Then let the trumpet sound a general doom,
These two being dead, then living is there none.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Tybalt is dead, and Romeo banished,
Romeo that murdered him is banished.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ah heavens, did Romeos hand shed Tybalts blood?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: It did, it did, alack the day it did.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O serpents hate, hid with a flowering face :
O painted sepulchre, including filth.
Was never book containing so foul matter,
So fairly bound. Ah, what meant Romeo?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: There is no truth, no faith, no honesty in men:
All false, all faithless, perjured, all forsworn.
Shame come to Romeo.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: A blister on that tongue, he was not borne to shame:
Upon his face Shame is ashamed to sit.
But wherefore villain didst thou kill my Cousin?
That villain Cousin would have killed my husband.
All this is comfort. But there yet remains
Worse than his death, which fain I would forget:
But ah, it presseth to my memory,
Romeo is banished. Ah that word Banished
Is worse than death. Romeo is banished,
Is Father, Mother, Tybalt, Iuliet,
All killed, all slain, all dead, all banished.
Where are my Father and my Mother Nurse?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Weeping and wailing over Tybalts corse.
Will you go to them?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Aye, Aye, when theirs are spent,
Mine shall he shed for Romeos banishment.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Lady, your Romeo will be here tonight,
I will to him, he is hid at Laurence Cell.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Do so, and bear this Ring to my true Knight,
And bid him come to take his last farewell.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Romeo come forth, come forth thou fearful man,
Affliction is enamoured on thy parts,
And thou art wedded to Calamity.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Father what news, what is the Princes doom,
What Sorrow craves acquaintance at our hands,
Which yet we know not.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Too familiar
Is my young son with such sour company:
I bring thee tidings of the Princes doom.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: What less than doomsday is the Princes doom?

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: A gentler judgment vanished from his lips,
Not bodies death, but bodies banishment.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Ha, Banished? be merciful, say death:
For Exile hath more terror in his looks,
Than death itself, do not say Banishment.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Hence from Verona art thou banished:
Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: There is no world without Verona walls,
But purgatory, torture, hell itself.
Hence banished, is banished from the world:
And world exiled is death. Calling death banishment,
Thou cuttest my head off with a golden axe,
And smilest upon the stroke that murders me.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: O monstrous sin, O rude unthankfulness:
Thy fault our law calls death, but the mild Prince
(Taking thy part) hath rushed aside the law,
And turned that black word death to banishment:
This is mere mercy, and thou seest it not.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: It is torture and not mercy, heaven is here
Where Iuliet lives: and every cat and dog,
And little mouse, every unworthy thing
Live here in heaven, and may look on her,
But Romeo may not. More validity,
More honourable state, more courtship lives
In carrion flies, than Romeo: they may seize
On the white wonder of fair Iuliets skin,
And steal immortal kisses from her lips;
But Romeo may not, he is banished.
Flies may do this, but I from this must fly.
O Father hadst thou no strong poison mixed,
No sharpe ground knife, no present mean of death,
Though never so mean, but banishment
To torture me withal: ah, banished.
O Friar, the damned use that word in hell:
Howling attends it. How hadst thou the heart,
Being a Divine, a ghostly Confessor,
A sin absolver, and my friend professed,
To mangle me with that word, Banishment?

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Thou fond mad man, hear me but speak a word.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: O, thou wilt talk again of Banishment.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: I will give thee armour to bear off this word,
Adversity's sweet milk, philosophy,
To comfort thee though thou be banished.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Yet Banished? hang up philosophy,
Unless philosophy can make a Iuliet,
Displant a Town, reverse a Princes doom,
It helps not, it prevails not, talk no more.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: O, now I see that madmen have no ears.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: How should they, when that wise men have no
eyes.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Let me dispute with thee of thy estate.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Thou canst not speak of what thou dost not feel.
Wert thou as young as I, Iuliet thy Love,
An hour but married, Tybalt murdered.
Doting like me, and like me banished,
Then mightst thou speak, then mightst thou tear thy
hair.
And fall upon the ground as I do now,
Taking the measure of an unmade grave.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Romeo arise, stand up thou wilt be taken,
I hear one knock, arise and get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Ho Fryer.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Gods will what wilfulness is this?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Ho Fryer open the door,

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: By and by I come. Who is there?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: One from Lady Iuliet.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Then come near.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: O holy Fryer, tell me o holy Fryer,
Where is my Ladies Lord? Where is Romeo?

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: There on the ground, with his own tears made
drunk.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: O he is even in my Mistress case.
Just in her case. O woeful sympathy,
Piteous predicament, even so lies she,
Weeping and blubbering, blubbering and weeping:
Stand up, stand up, stand and you be a man.
For Iuliets sake, for her sake rise and stand,
Why should you fall into so deep an O.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Ah sir, ah sir. Well death's the end of all.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Spakest thou of Iuliet, how is it with her?
Doth she not think me an old murderer,
Now I have stained the childhood of her joy,
With blood removed but little from her own?
Where is she? and how doth she? And what says
My concealed Lady to our concealed love?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: O she saith nothing, but weeps and pules,
And now falls on her bed, now on the ground,
And Tybalt cries, and then on Romeo calls.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: As if that name shot from the deadly level of a gun
Did murder her, as that names cursed hand
Murdered her kinsman. Ah tell me holy Fryer
In what vile part of this Anatomy
Doth my name lie? Tell me that I may sack
The hateful mansion?

stage.l: He offers to stab himselfe, and Nurse snatches

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Ah?

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Hold, stay thy hand: art thou a man? thy form
Cries out thou art, but thy wild acts denote
The unreasonable furies of a beast.
Unseemly woman in a seeming man,
Or ill beseeming beast in seeming both.
Thou hast amazed me. By my holy order,
I thought thy disposition better tempered,
Hast thou slain Tybalt? wilt thou slay thyself?
And slay thy Lady too, that lives in thee?
Rouse up thy spirits, thy Lady Iuliet lives,
For whose sweet sake thou wert but lately dead:
There art thou happy. Tybalt would kill thee,
But thou slewest Tybalt, there art thou happy too.
A pack of blessings lights upon thy back,
Happiness Courts thee in his best array:
But like a misbehaved and sullen wench
Thou frownest upon thy Fate that smiles on thee.
Take heed, take heed, for such dye miserable.
Go get thee to thy love as was decreed:
Ascend her Chamber Window, hence and comfort her,
But look thou stay not till the watch be set:
For then thou canst not pass to Mantua.
Nurse provide all things in a readiness,
Comfort thy Mistress, haste the house to bed,
Which heavy sorrow makes them apt unto.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Good Lord what a thing learning is.
I could have stayed here all this night
To hear good counsel. Well Sir,
I will tell my Lady that you will come.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Do so and bid my sweet prepare to child,
Farewell good Nurse.

stage.l: Nurse offers to go in and turnes again.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Here is a Ring Sir, that she bad me give you,

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: How well my comfort is revived by this.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Soiorne in Mantua, I will find out your man,
And he shall signify from time to time:
Every good hap that doth befall thee here.
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: But that a joy, past joy cries out on me,
It were a grief so brief to part with thee.

stage.l: Enter olde Capolet and his Wife, With

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Things have fallen out Sir so unluckily,
That we have had no time to move my daughter.
Look ye Sir, she loved her kinsman dearly,
And so did I. Well, we were borne to dye,
Wife where is your daughter, is she in her chamber?
I think she means not to come down tonight.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: These times of woe afford no time to woo,
Madam farewell, commend me to your daughter.

stage.l: Paris offers to go in, and Capolet

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Sir Paris? I will make a desperate tender of my child.
I think she will be ruled in all respects by me:
But soft what day is this?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Monday my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: O then Wednesday is too soon,
On Thursday let it be: you shall be married.
We will make no great ado, a friend or two, or so:
For look ye Sir, Tybalt being slain so lately,
It will be thought we held him carelessly:
If we should revel much, therefore we will have
Some half a dozen friends and make no more ado.
But what say you to Thursday.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My Lord I wish that Thursday were tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Wife go you to your daughter, ere you go to
bed.
Acquaint her with the County Paris love,
Fare well my Lord till Thursday next.
Wife get you to your daughter. Light to my Chamber.
Afore me it is so very very late,
That we may call it early by and by.

stage.l: Enter Romeo and Iuliet at the window.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Wilt thou be gone? It is not yet near day,
It was the Nightingale and not the Lark
That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear:
Nightly she sings on yon Pomegranate tree,
Believe me love, it was the Nightingale.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: It was the Lark, the Herald of the Morn,
And not the Nightingale. See Love what envious streaks
Do lace the severing clouds in yonder East.
Nights candles are burnt out, and jocund Day
Stands tiptoes on the misty mountain tops.
I must be gone and live, or stay and dye.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Yon light is not day light, I know it I:
It is some Meteor that the Sun exhales,
To be this night to thee a Torch-bearer,
And light thee on thy way to Mantua.
Then stay awhile, thou shalt not go soon.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Let me stay here, let me be taken, and dye:
If thou wilt have it so, I am content.
I will say yon gray is not the Mornings Eye,
It is the pale reflex of Cynthias brow.
I will say it is the Nightingale that bears
The vaulty heaven so high above our heads,
And not the Lark the Messenger of Morn.
Come death and welcome, Iuliet wills it so.
What says my Love? let us talk, it is not yet day.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: It is, it is, be gone, fly hence away.
It is the Lark that sings so out of tune,
Straining harsh Discords and unpleasing Sharps.
Some say, the Lark makes sweet Division:
This doth not so: for this divideth us.
Some say the Lark and loathed Toad change eyes,
I would that now they had changed voices too:
Since arm from arm her voice doth us affray,
Hunting thee hence with Hunt's-up to the day.
So now be gone, more light and light it grows.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: More light and light, more dark and dark our
woes.
Farewell my Love, one kiss and I will descend.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Art thou gone so, my Lord, my Love, my Friend?
I must hear from thee every day in the hour:
For in an hour there are many minutes,
Minutes are days, so will I number them:
O by this count I shall be much in years,
Ere I see thee again.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Farewell, I will omit no opportunity
That may convey my greetings love to thee.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O, thinkst thou we shall ever meet again.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: No doubt, no doubt, and all this woe shall serve
For sweet discourses in the time to come.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O God, I have an ill divining soul.
Methinks I see thee now thou art below
Like one dead in the bottom of a Tomb:
Either mine eyesight fails, or thou lookest pale.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: And trust me Love, in my eye so do you,
Dry sorrow drinks our blood: adieu, adieu.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Madam beware, take heed the day is broke,
Your Mother's coming to your Chamber, make all sure.

stage.l: She goeth downe from the window.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Where are you Daughter?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: What Lady, Lamb, what Iuliet?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: How now, who calls?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: It is your Mother.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Why how now Iuliet?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Madam, I am not well.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: What evermore weeping for your Cousin's death:
I think thou wilt wash him from his grave with tears.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I cannot choose, having so great a loss.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: I cannot blame thee.
But it grieves thee more that Villain lives.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What Villain Madam?

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: That Villain Romeo.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Villain and he are many miles a sunder.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Content thee Girl, if I could find a man
I soon would send to Mantua where he is,
That should bestow on him so sure a draught,
As he should soon bear Tybalt company.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Find you the means, and I will find such a man:
For whilst he lives, my heart shall never be light
Till I behold him, dead is my poor heart.
Thus for a Kinsman vexed?

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Well let that pass. I come to bring thee joyful news?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And joy comes well in such a needful time.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Well then, thou hast a careful Father Girl,
And one who pitying thy needful state,
Hath found thee out a happy day of joy.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What day is that I pray you?

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Marry my Child,
The gallant, young and youthful Gentlemen,
The County Paris at Saint Peters Church,
Early next Thursday morning must provide,
To make you there a glad and joyful Bride.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Now by Saint Peters Church and Peter too,
He shall not there make me a joyful Bride.
Are these the news you had to tell me of?
Marry here are news indeed. Madam I will not marry
yet.
And when I do, it shall be rather Romeo whom I hate,
Than County Paris that I cannot love.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Here comes your Father, you may tell him so.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why how now, evermore showering?
In one little body thou resemblest a sea, a bark, a storm:
For this thy body which I term a bark,
Still floating in thy ever-falling tears,
And tossed with sighs arising from thy hart:
Will without succour ship wreck presently.
But hear you Wife, what have you sounded her, what says
she to it?

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: I have, but she will none she thanks ye:
Would God that she were married to her grave.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: What will she not, doth she not thank us, doth
she not wax proud?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Not proud ye have, but thankful that ye have:
Proud can I never be of that I hate,
But thankful even for hate that is meant love.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Proud and I thank you, and I thank you not,
And yet not proud. What is here, chop logic.
Proud me no prouds, nor thank me no thanks,
But settle your fine joints on Thursday next
To go with Paris to Saint Peters Church,
Or I will drag you on a hurdle thither.
Out you green sickness baggage, out you tallow face.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Good father hear me speak?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I tell thee what, either resolve on thursday next
To go with Paris to Saint Peters Church:
Or henceforth never look me in the face.
Speak not, reply not, for my fingers itch.
Why wife, we thought that we were scarcely blessed
That God had sent us but this only child:
But now I see this one is one too much,
And that we have a cross in having her.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Marry God in heaven bless her my Lord,
You are to blame to rate her so.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: And why my Lady wisdom? hold your tongue,
Good prudence smatter with your gossips, go.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Why my Lord I speak no treason.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: O goddegodden.
Utter your gravity over a gossips bowl,
For here we need it not.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: My Lord ye are too hot.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Gods blessed mother wife it mads me,
Day, night, early, late, at home, abroad,
Alone, in company, waking or sleeping,
Still my care hath been to see her matched.
And having how found out a Gentleman,
Of Princely parentage, youthful, and nobly trained.
Stuffed as they say with honourable parts,
Proportioned as ones heart could wish a man:
And then to have a wretched whining fool,
A puling mammet in her fortunes tender,
To say I cannot love, I am too young, I pray you pardon
me?
But if you cannot wed I will pardon you.
