Graze where you will, you shall not house with me.
Look to it, think on it, I do not use to jest.
I tell ye what, Thursday is near,
Lay hand on heart, advise, bethink yourself,
If you be mine, I will give you to my friend:
If not, hang, drown, starve, beg,
Dye in the streets: for by my Soul
I will never more acknowledge thee,
Nor what I have shall ever do thee good,
Think on it, look toot, I do not use to jest.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Is there no pity hanging in the clouds,
That looks into the bottom of my woes?
I do beseech you Madam, cast me not away,
Defer this marriage for a day or two,
Or if you cannot, make my marriage bed
In that dim monument where Tybalt lies.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Nay be assured I will not speak a word.
Do what thou wilt for I have done with thee.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Ah Nurse what comfort? what counsel canst thou
give me.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Now trust me Madam, I know not what to say:
Your Romeo he is banished, and all the world to nothing
He never dares return to challenge you.
Now I think good you marry with this County,
O he is a gallant Gentleman, Romeo is but a dishclout
In respect of him. I promise you
I think you happy in this second match.
As for your husband he is dead:
Or it were as good he were, for you have no use of him.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Speakest thou this from thy heart?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: I and from my soul, of else beshrew them both.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: What say you Madam?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Well, thou hast comforted me wondrous much,
I pray thee go thy ways unto my mother
Tell her I am gone having displeased my Father.
To Fryer Laurence Cell to confess me,
And to be absolved.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: I will, and this is wisely done.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ancient damnation, O most cursed fiend.
Is it more sin to wish me thus forsworn,
Or to dispraise him with the self-same tongue
That thou hast praised him with above compare
So many thousand times? Go Counsellor,
Thou and my bosom henceforth shall be twain.
I will to the Fryer to know his remedy,
If all fail else, I have the power to dye.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: On Thursday say ye: the time is very short,

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My Father Capolet will have it so,
And I am nothing slack to slow his haste.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: You say you do not know the Ladies mind?
Uneven is the course, I like it not.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Immoderately she weeps for Tybalts death,
And therefore have I little talked of love.
For Venus smiles not in a house of tears,
Now Sir, her father thinks it dangerous:
That she doth give her sorrow so much sway.
And in his wisdom hastes our marriage,
To stop the inundation of her tears.
Which too much minded by herself alone
May be put from her by society.
Now do ye know the reason of this haste.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: I would I knew not why it should be slowed.
Here comes the Lady to my cell,

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Welcome my love, my Lady and my wife:

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: That may be sir, when I may be a wife,

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: That may be, must be love, on thursday next.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What must be shall be.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: That is a certain text.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What come ye to confession to this Fryer.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: To tell you that were to confess to you.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Do not deny to him that you love me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I will confess to you that I love him,

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: So I am sure you will that you love me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And if I do, it will be of more price,
Being spoke behind your back, than to your face.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Poor soul thy face is much abused with tears.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: The tears have got small victory by that,
For it was bad enough before their spite.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Thou wrongest it more than tears by that report.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: That is no wrong sir, that is a truth:
And what I spake I spake it to my face.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Thy face is mine and thou hast slandered it.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: It may be so, for it is not mine own.
Are you at leisure holy Father now:
Or shall I come to you at evening Mass?

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: My leisure serves me pensive daughter now.
My Lord we must entreat the time alone.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: God shield I should disturb devotion,
Iuliet farewell, and keep this holy kiss.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Go shut the door and when thou hast done so,
Come weep with me that am past cure, past help,

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Ah Iuliet I already know thy grief,
I hear thou must and nothing may prorogue it,
On Thursday next be married to the County.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Tell me not Friar that thou hearst of it,
Unless thou tell me how we may prevent it.
Give me some sudden counsel: else behold
Twixt my extremes and me, this bloody Knife
Shall play the Umpire, arbitrating that
Which the Commission of thy years and art
Could to no issue of true honour bring.
Speak not, be brief: for I desire to die,
If what thou speakest, speak not of remedy.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Stay Iuliet, I do spy a kind of hope,
Which craves as desperate an execution,
As that is desperate we would prevent.
If rather than to marry County Paris
Thou hast the strength or will to slay thyself,
It is not unlike that thou wilt undertake
A thing like death to chide away this shame,
That copest with death itself to fly from blame.
And if thou dost, I will give thee remedy.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O bid me leap (rather than marry Paris)
From off the battlements of yonder tower:
Or chain me to some steepy mountain's top,
Where roaring Bears and savage Lions are:
Or shut me nightly in a Charnel-house,
With reeky shanks, and yellow chapless sculls:
Or lay me in tomb with one new dead:
Things that to hear them named have made me tremble;
And I will do it without fear or doubt,
To keep myself a faithful unstained Wife
To my dear Lord, my dearest Romeo.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Hold Iuliet, hie thee home, get thee to bed,
Let not thy Nurse lie with thee in thy Chamber:
And when thou art alone, take thou this Vial,
And this distilled Liquor drink thou off:
When presently through all thy veins shall run
A dull and heavy slumber, which shall seize
Each vital spirit: for no Pulse shall keep
His natural progress, but surcease to beat:
No sign of breath shall testify thou livest.
And in this borrowed likeness of shrunk death,
Thou shalt remain full two and forty hours.
And when thou art laid in thy Kindreds Vault,
I will send in haste to Mantua to thy Lord,
And he shall come and take thee from thy grave.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Friar I go, be sure thou send for my dear Romeo.

stage.l: Enter olde Capolet, his Wife, Nurse, and

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Where are you sirrah?

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p: Here forsooth.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Go, provide me twenty cunning Cooks.

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p:
I warrant you Sir, let me alone for that, I will know
them by licking their fingers.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How canst thou know them so?

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p: Ah Sir, it is an ill Cook cannot lick his own fingers.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Well get you gone.
But where is this Head-strong?

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: She is gone (my Lord) to Friar Laurence Cell
To be confessed.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Ah, he may hap to do some good of her,
A headstrong self-wild harlotry it is.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: See here she cometh from Confession,

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How now my Head-strong, where have you been
gadding?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Where I have learned to repent the sin
Of froward wilful opposition
Gainst you and your behests, and am enjoined
By holy Laurence to fall prostrate here,
And crave remission of so foul a fact.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Why that is well said.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Now before God this holy reverent Friar
All our whole City is much bound unto.
Go tell the County presently of this,
For I will have this knot knit up tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Nurse, will you go with me to my Closet,
To sort such things as shall be requisite
Against tomorrow.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: I prithee do, good Nurse go in with her,
Help her to sort Tires, Rebatos, Chains,
And I will come unto you presently,

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Come sweet hart, shall we go?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I prithee let us.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Me thinks on Thursday would be time enough.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I say I will have this dispatched tomorrow,
Go one and certify the Count thereof.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: I pray my Lord, let it be Thursday.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I say tomorrow while she is in the mood.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: We shall be short in our provision.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Let me alone for that, go get you in,
Now before God my heart is passing light,
To see her thus conformed to our will.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Come, come, what need you any thing else?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Nothing good Nurse, but leave me to myself:
For I do mean to lie alone tonight.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Well there is a clean smock under your pillow,
and so good night.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: What are you busy, do you need my help?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: No Madam, I desire to lie alone,
For I have many things to think upon.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Well then good night, be stirring Iuliet,
The County will be early here tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Farewell, God knows when we shall meet again.
Ah, I do take a fearful thing in hand.
What if this Potion should not work at all,
Must I of force be married to the County?
This shall forbid it. Knife, lie thou there.
What if the Friar should give me this drink
To poison me, for fear I should disclose
Our former marriage? Ah, I wrong him much,
He is a holy and religious Man:
I will not entertain so bad a thought.
What if I should be stifled in the Tomb?
Awake an hour before the appointed time:
An then I fear I shall be lunatic,
And playing with my dead forefathers bones,
Dash out my frantic brains. Methinks I see
My Cousin Tybalt weltering in his blood,
Seeking for Romeo: stay Tybalt stay.
Romeo I come, this do I drink to thee.

stage.l: She fals vpon her bed within the Curtaines.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: That is well said Nurse, set all in readiness,
The County will be here immediately.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Make haste, make haste, for it is almost day,
The Curfew bell hath rung, it is four o'clock,
Look to your baked meats good Angelica.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Go get you to bed you cotquean. I faith you
will be sick anon.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I warrant thee Nurse I have ere now watched all
night, and have taken no harm at all.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: I you have been a mouse hunt in your time.

stage.l: Enter a Seruingman with Logs and Coales.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A Jealous-hood hood, a Jealous-hood: How now sirrah?
What have you there?

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.l: Forsooth Logs.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Go, go choose dryer. Will will tell thee where
thou shalt fetch them.

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.l: Nay I warrant let me alone, I have a head I trow to
choose a Log.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Well go thy way, thou shalt be logger head.
Come, come, make haste call up your daughter,
The County will be here with music straight.
Gods me he is come, Nurse call up my daughter.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Go, get you gone. What lamb, what Lady
bird? fast I warrant. What Iuliet? well, let the County take
you in your bed, ye sleep for a week now, but the next
night, the County Paris hath set up his rest that you shall rest
but little. What lamb I say, fast still: what Lady, Love,
what bride, what Iuliet? Gods me how sound she sleeps? Nay
then I see I must wake you indeed. What is here, laid on
your bed, dressed in your clothes and down, ah me, alack the
day, some Aqua vitae ho.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: How now what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Alack the day, she is dead, she is dead, she is dead.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Accursed, unhappy, miserable time.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Come, come, make haste, wheres my daughter?

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: Ah she is dead, she is dead.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Stay, let me see, all pale and wan.
Accursed time, unfortunate old man.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What is the bride ready to go to Church?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Ready to go, but never to return.
O Son the night before thy wedding day,
Hath Death lain with thy bride, flower as she is,
Deflowered by him, see, where she lies,
Death is my son-in-law, to him I give all that I have.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Have I thought long to see this mornings face,
And doth it now present such prodigies?
Accursed, unhappy, miserable man,
Forlorn, forsaken, destitute I am:
Borne to the world to be a slave in it.
Distressed, remediless, and unfortunate.
O heavens, O nature, wherefore did you make me,
To live so vile, so wretched as I shall.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: O here she lies that was our hope, our joy,
And being dead, dead sorrow nips us all.

stage.l: All at once cry out and wring their hands

sp.l: All our joy, and all our hope is dead,
Dead, lost, undone, absented, wholly fled.
Cruel, unjust, impartial destinies,
Why to this day have you preserved my life?
Too see my hope, my stay, my joy, my life,
Deprived of sense, of life, of all by death,
Cruel, unjust, impartial destinies.
O sad faced sorrow map of misery,
Why this sad time have I desired to see.
This day, this unjust, this impartial day
Wherein I hoped to see my comfort full,
To be deprived by sudden destiny.

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: O woe, alack, distressed, why should I live?
To see this day, this miserable day.
Alack the time that ever I was borne,
To be partaker of this destiny.
Alack the day, alack and well-a-day.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: O peace for shame, if not for charity.
Your daughter lives in peace and happiness,
And it is vain to wish it otherwise.
Come stick your Rosemary in this dead coarse,
And as the custom of our Country is,
In all her best and sumptuous ornaments,
Convey her where her Ancestors lie tombed,

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Let it be so, come woeful sorrow mates,
Let us together taste this bitter fate.

stage.l: They all but the Nurse go foorth, casting Rosemary on

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Put up, put up, this is a woeful case.

sp.speaker: Mus-1.
sp.p: I by my troth Mistress is it, it had need be mended.

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p: Alack alack what shall I do, come Fiddlers play me
some merry dump.

sp.speaker: Mus-1.
sp.p: A sir, this is no time to play.

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p: You will not then?

sp.speaker: Mus-1.
sp.p: No marry will we.

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p: Then will I give it you, and soundly too.

sp.speaker: Mus-1.
sp.p: What will you give us?

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p: The fiddler, I will re you, I will fa you I will sol you.

sp.speaker: Mus-1.
sp.p: If you re us and fa us, we will note you.

sp.speaker: Ser-men.
sp.p: I will put up my Iron dagger, and beat you with
my wooden wit. Come on Simon found Pot, I will pose you,

sp.speaker: Mus-1.
sp.p: Let us hear.

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p: When griping grief the heart doth wound,
And doleful dumps the mind oppress:
Then music with her silver sound,
Why silver sound? Why silver sound?

sp.speaker: Mus-1.
sp.p: I think because music hath a sweet sound.

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p: Pretty, what say you Mathew minikin?

sp.speaker: Mus-2.
sp.p: I think because Musicians sound for silver.

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p: Pretty too: come, what say you?

sp.speaker: Mus-3.
sp.p: I say nothing.

sp.speaker: Ser-man.
sp.p: I think so, I will speak for you because you are the
Singer. I say Silver sound, because such Fellows as you
have seldom Gold for sounding. Farewell Fiddlers, farewell.

sp.speaker: Mus-1.
sp.p: Farewell and be hanged: come let us go.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: If I may trust the flattering Eye of Sleep,
My Dream presaged some good event to come.
My bosom Lord sits cheerful in his throne,
And I am comforted with pleasing dreams.
Me thought I was this night already dead:
(Strange dreams that give a dead man leave to think)
And that my Lady Iuliet came to me,
And breathed such life with kisses in my lips,
That I revived and was an Emperor.
News from Verona. How now Balthasar,
How doth my Lady? Is my Father well?
How fares my Iuliet? that I ask again:
If she be well, then nothing can be ill.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Then nothing can be ill, for she is well,
Her body sleeps in Capels Monument,
And her immortal parts with Angels dwell.
Pardon me Sir, that am the Messenger of such bad tidings.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Is it even so? then I defy my Stars.
Go get me ink and paper, hire post horse,
I will not stay in Mantua tonight.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Pardon me Sir, I will not leave you thus,
Your looks are dangerous and full of fear:
I dare not, nor I will not leave you yet.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Do as I bid thee, get me ink and paper,
And hire those horse: stay not I say.
Well Iuliet, I will lie with thee tonight.
Let us see for means. As I do remember
Here dwells a Apothecary whom oft I noted
As I past by, whose needy shop is stuffed
With beggarly accounts of empty boxes:
And in the same an Aligarta hangs,
Old ends of pack-thread, and cakes of Roses,
Are thinly strewed to make up a show.
Him as I noted, thus with myself I thought:
And if a man should need a poison now,
(Whose present sale is death in Mantua)
Here he might buy it. This thought of mine
Did but forerun my need: and here about he dwells.
Being Holiday the Beggar's shop is shut.
What ho Apothecary, come forth I say.

sp.speaker: Apo.
sp.l: Who calls, what would you sir?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Here is twenty ducats,
Give me a dram of some such speeding gear,
As will dispatch the weary takers life,
As suddenly as powder being fired
From forth a Cannons mouth.

sp.speaker: Apo.
sp.l: Such drugs I have I must of force confess,
But yet the law is death to those that sell them.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Art thou so bare and full of poverty,
And dost thou fear to violate the Law?
The Law is not thy friend, nor the Law's friend,
And therefore make no conscience of the law:
Upon thy back hangs ragged Misery,
And starved Famine dwelleth in thy cheeks.

sp.speaker: Apo.
sp.l: My poverty but not my will consents.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I pay thy poverty, but not thy will.

sp.speaker: Apo.
sp.p: Hold take you this, and put it in any liquid thing
you will, and it will serve had you the lives of twenty men.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Hold, take this gold, worse poison to men's souls
Than this which thou hast given me. Go hie thee hence,
Go buy the clothes, and get thee into flesh.
Come cordial and not poison, go with me
To Iuliets Grave: for there must I use thee.

sp.speaker: Fri I.
sp.l: What Friar Laurence, Brother, ho?

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: This same should be the voice of Friar Iohn.
What news from Mantua, what will Romeo come?

sp.speaker: Fri I.
sp.l: Going to seek a barefoot Brother out,
One of our order to associate me,
Here in this City visiting the sick,
Whereas the infectious pestilence remained:
And being by the Searchers of the Town
Found and examined, we were both shut up.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Who bare my letters then to Romeo?

sp.speaker: Fri I.
sp.l: I have them still, and here they are.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Now by my holy Order,
The letters were not nice, but of great weight.
Go get thee hence, and get me presently
A spade and a mattock.

sp.speaker: Fri I.
sp.l: Well I will presently go fetch thee them.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Now must I to the Monument alone,
Least that the Lady should before I come
Be waked from sleep. I will hie
To free her from that Tomb of misery.

stage.l: Enter Countie Paris and his Page with flowers

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Put out the torch, and lie thee all along
Under this Yew-tree, keeping thine ear close to the hollow
ground.
And if thou hear one tread within this Churchyard,
Straight give me notice.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I will my Lord.

stage.l: Paris strewes the Tomb with flowers.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Sweet Flower, with flowers I strew thy Bridal
bed:
Sweet Tomb that in thy circuit dost contain,
The perfect model of eternity:
Fair Iuliet that with Angels dost remain,
Accept this latest favour at my hands,
That living honoured thee, and being dead
With funeral praises do adorn thy Tomb.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: My Lord.

stage.l: Enter Romeo and Balthasar, with a torch, a
a mattocke, and a crow of yron.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: The boy gives warning, something doth approach.
What cursed foot wanders this was tonight,
To stay my obsequies and true love's rites?
What with a torch, muffle me night a while.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Give me this mattock, and this wrenching Iron.
And take these letters early in the morning,
See thou deliver them to my Lord and Father.
So get thee gone and trouble me no more.
Why I descend into this bed of death,
Is partly to behold my Ladies face,
But chiefly to take from her dead finger,
A precious ring which I must use
In dear employment but if thou wilt stay,
Further to pry in what I undertake,
By heaven I will tear thee joint by joint,
And strew this hungry churchyard with thy limbs.
The time and my intents are savage, wild.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Well, I will be gone and not trouble you.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: So shalt thou win my favour, take thou this,
Commend me to my Father, farewell good fellow.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: :Yet for all this will I not part from hence.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Thou detestable maw, thou womb of death,
Gored with the dearest morsel of the earth.
Thus I enforce thy rotten jaws to ope.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: This is that banished haughty Mountague,
That murdered my love's cousin, I will apprehend him.
Stop thy unhallowed toil vile Mountague.
Can vengeance be pursued further then death?
I do attach thee as a felon here.
The Law condemns thee, therefore thou must dye.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I must indeed, and therefore came I hither,
Good youth begone, tempt not a desperate man.
Heap not another sin upon my head
By shedding of thy blood, I do protest
I love thee better then I love myself:
For I come hither armed against myself.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I do defy thy conjurations:
And do attach thee as a felon here.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: What dost thou tempt me, then have at thee boy.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: O Lord they fight, I will go call the watch.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Ah I am slain, if thou be merciful
Open the tomb, lay me with Iuliet.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Yfaith I will, let me peruse this face,
Mercutios kinsman, noble County Paris?
What said my man, when my betossed soul
Did not regard him as we past a long.
Did he not say Paris should have married
Iuliet? either he said so, or I dreamed it so.
But I will satisfy thy last request,
For thou hast prized thy love above thy life.
Death lie thou there, by a dead man interred,
How oft have many at the hour of death
Been blithe and pleasant? which their keepers call
A lightning before death But how may I
Call this a lightning. Ah dear Iuliet,
How well thy beauty doth become this grave?
O I believe that unsubstantial death,
Is amorous, and doth court my love.
Therefore will I, O here, O ever here,
Set up my everlasting rest
With worms, that are thy chamber maids.
Come desperate Pilot now at once run on
The dashing rocks thy seasick weary barge.
Here is to my love. O true Apothecary:
Thy drugs are swift: thus with a kiss I dye.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: How oft tonight have these my aged feet
Stumbled at graves as I did pass along.
Who is there?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: A friend and one that knows you well.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Who is it that consorts so late the dead,
What light is yon? if I be not deceived,
Methinks it burns in Capels monument?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: It doth so holy Sir, and there is one
That loves you dearly.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Who is it?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Romeo.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: How long hath he been there?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Full half an hour and more.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Go with me thither.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I dare not sir, he knows not I am here:
On pain of death he charged me to be gone,
And not for to disturb him in his enterprise.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Then must I go: my mind presageth ill.

stage.l: Fryer stoops and lookes on the blood and weapons.

sp.l: What blood is this that stains the entrance
Of this marble stony monument?
What means these masterless and gory weapons?
Ah me I doubt, who is here? what Romeo dead?
Who and Paris too? what unlucky hour
Is accessory to so foul a sin?
The Lady stirs.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ah comfortable Fryer.
I do remember well where I should be,
And what we talked of: but yet I cannot see
Him for whose sake I undertook this hazard.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: Lady come forth. I hear some noise at hand,
We shall be taken, Paris, he is slain,
And Romeo dead: and if we here be taken
We shall be thought to be as accessory.
I will provide for you in some close Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ah leave me, leave me, I will not from hence.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: I hear some noise, I dare not stay, come, come.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Go get thee gone.
What is here a cup closed in my lover's hands?
Ah churl drink all, and leave no drop for me.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: This way, this way.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Aye, noise? then must I be resolute.
O happy dagger thou shalt end my fear,
Rest in my bosom, thus I come to thee.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Come look about, what weapons have we here?
See friends where Iuliet two days buried,
New bleeding wounded, search and see who is near.
Attach and bring them to us presently.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Captain here is a Fryer with tools about him,
Fit to ope a tomb.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: A great suspicion, keep him safe.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Here is Romeos Man.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Keep him to be examined.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: What early mischief calls us up so soon.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: O noble Prince, see here
Where Iuliet that hath lain entombed two days,
Warm and fresh bleeding, Romeo and County Paris
Likewise newly slain.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Search seek about to find the murderers.

stage.l: Enter olde Capolet and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: What rumour is this that is so early up?

sp.speaker: L Cap.
sp.l: The people in the streets cry Romeo,
And some on Iuliet: as if they alone
Had been the cause of such a mutiny.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: See Wife, this dagger hath mistook:
For (lo) the back is empty of young Mountague,
And it is sheathed in our Daughters breast.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Come Mountague, for thou art early up,
To see thy Son and Heir more early down.

sp.speaker: Mou.
sp.l: Dread Sovereign, my Wife is dead tonight,
And young Benuolio is deceased too:
What further mischief can there yet be found?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: First come and see, then speak.

sp.speaker: Mou.
sp.l: O thou untaught, what manners is in this
To press before thy Father to a grave.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Come seal your mouths of outrage for a while,
And let us seek to find the Authors out
Of such a heinous and seld seen mischance.
Bring forth the parties in suspicion.

sp.speaker: Fri L.
sp.l: I am the greatest able to do least.
Most worthy Prince, hear me but speak the truth.
And I will inform you how these things fell out.
Iuliet here slain was married to that Romeo,
Without her Fathers or her Mothers grant:
The Nurse was privy to the marriage.
The baleful day of this unhappy marriage,
Was Tybalts doomsday: for which Romeo
Was banished from hence to Mantua.
He gone, her Father sought by foul constraint
To marry her to Paris: but her Soul
(Loathing a second Contract) did refuse
To give consent; and therefore did she urge me
Either to find a means she might avoid
What so her Father sought to force her too:
Or else all desperately she threatened
Even in my presence to dispatch herself.
Then did I give her, (tutored by mine art)
A potion that should make her seem as dead:
And told her that I would with all post speed
Send hence to Mantua for her Romeo,
That he might come and take her from the Tomb.
But he that had my Letters (Friar Iohn)
Seeking a Brother to associate him,
Whereas the sick infection remained,
Was stayed by the Searchers of the Town.
But Romeo understanding by his man,
That Iuliet was deceased, returned in post
Unto Verona for to see his love.
What after happened touching Paris death,
Or Romeos is to me unknown at all.
But when I came to take the Lady hence,
I found them dead, and she awaked from sleep:
Whom fain I would have taken from the tomb,
Which she refused seeing Romeo dead.
Anon I heard the watch and then I fled,
What after happened I am ignorant of.
And if in this ought have miscarried
By me, or by my means let my old life
Be sacrificed some hour before his time.
To the most strictest rigour of the Law.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: We still have known thee for a holy man,
Wheres Romeos man, what can he say in this?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I brought my master word that she was dead,
And then he posted straight from Mantua,
Unto this Tomb. These Letters he delivered me,
Charging me early give them to his Father.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Let us see the Letters, I will read them over.
Where is the Counties Boy that called the Watch?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: I brought my Master unto Iuliets grave,
But one approaching, straight I called my Master.
At last they fought, I ran to call the Watch.
And this is all that I can say or know.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: These letters do make good the Fryers words,
Come Capolet, and come old Mountagewe.
Where are these enemies? see what hate hath done,

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Come brother Mountague give me thy hand,
There is my daughters dowry: for now no more
Can I bestow on her, that is all I have.

sp.speaker: Mou.
sp.l: But I will give them more, I will erect
Her statue of pure gold:
That while Verona by that name is known.
There shall no statue of such price be set,
As that of Romeos loved Iuliet.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: As rich shall Romeo by his Lady lie,
Poor Sacrifices to our Enmity.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: A gloomy peace this day doth with it bring.
Come, let us hence,
To have more talk of these sad things.
Some shall be pardoned and some punished:
For never was heard a Story of more woe,
Than this of Iuliet and her Romeo.
